    a

    Antiproliferation activity of the conjugate, absolute concentration; time point was 6 days.

    b

    Antiproliferation activity, unconjugated degrader, or conjugated chimeric degrader drug-equivalents; time point was 6 days.

    c

    Ratio of STEAP1 and CLL1 IC50 values for the given linker-drug. NA, not applicable.

    The CLL1–8a conjugate was subsequently advanced into an in vivo efficacy study employing the HL-60 xenograft model where it exhibited promising dose-dependent antitumor activity following single IV administrations (Figure 15). Importantly, at a matched dose of 10 mg/kg, the efficacy noted for the corresponding STEAP1–8a control conjugate was considerably attenuated relative to that displayed by CLL1–8a. These experiments provided additional evidence that antibody conjugates bearing chimeric BRD4 degraders could successfully deliver such payloads to tumors in an antigen-dependent manner. As was the case for the PC3-S1 in vivo studies described above, mouse body weight changes were acceptable throughout the course of the HL-60 experiments with CLL1–8a and STEAP1–8a (Figure S12).
    We concluded our in vivo efficacy profiling work by examining conjugates derived from linker-drug 13a in the HL-60 xenograft model. Similar to what was observed for the CLL1–8a ADC, CLL1–13a displayed strong, dose-dependent TGI effects in this assessment with the efficacy outcomes well-separated from those observed for the corresponding STEAP1–13a control conjugate (Figure 16a). To probe the origin of the in vivo activity associated with CLL1–13a, we performed a second experiment in the HL-60 model, which compared the former conjugate to the DAR6 CLL1–14a ADC. The latter entity was constructed from chimeric degrader 14, which contained a 4(S)-hydroxyproline moiety and was thus not expected to bind to VHL, form a ternary complex with BRD4 and VHL, and/or degrade the BRD4 protein in cells (Figure 9; also see biological results for the related compound 10, Figure 5 and Table 1). When administered to xenografted mice at a dose of 10 mg/kg, CLL1–14a displayed no efficacy in the HL-60 assessment (Figure 16b). This lack of activity was in stark contrast to the strong TGI outcomes observed for CLL1–13a at the same 10 mg/kg dose in this experiment (Figure 16b). Collectively, the results underscored a critical requirement for the conjugated payloads to possess potent BRD4 degradation activities, as opposed to only potent BRD4 binding affinities, in order for the related ADCs to afford strong in vivo antitumor properties. In addition, a DAR6 CLL1-targeting conjugate that was derived from a linker-drug that lacked a BRD4-binding moiety was inactive in the HL-60 in vivo model (CLL1–16, Figures 16b and 17). This outcome demonstrated that the encouraging HL-60 efficacy noted for CLL1–13a did not result from direct inhibition of the VHL protein. An unconjugated CLL1 mAb was also not active in the HL-60 xenograft assessment, thereby confirming that antibody-related bioactivity did not meaningfully contribute to the CLL1–13a efficacy results (Figure 16b). Importantly, all of the tested conjugates were well-tolerated with acceptable mouse body weight changes noted throughout the course of the experiments (Figure S13a,b).
    In addition to profiling the CLL1–13a conjugate in the various in vivo efficacy studies described above, we also examined the in vivo stability and pharmacokinetic properties associated with the ADC. As shown in Figure 18, analysis of plasma samples obtained from mice during the course of the initial HL-60 in vivo experiment (Figure 16a) demonstrated that CLL1–13a exhibited excellent in vivo stability properties with minimal retro-Michael-reaction loss of the attached linker-drug or biotransformation of the chimeric degrader payload (also see Figure S14). Similar favorable stability outcomes were observed for the conjugate in a separate mouse pharmacokinetic study over a 7 day period (data not shown). Liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LCMS)/MS-based assessments of the same plasma samples also determined that CLL1–13a exhibited a favorable total antibody pharmacokinetic profile that was similar to that determined previously for the unconjugated CLL1 mAb (Figure 19; note the differing doses of the two entities).(37) When combined with the in vivo stability and pharmacokinetic data from the initial phase of our studies,(16) the results depicted in Figures 18 and 19 demonstrate the general ability of the described conjugation approaches to generate chimeric protein degrader conjugates with attractive in vivo properties. However, as was also mentioned in the descriptions of our earlier research, additional experimentation is needed to (1) better define the pharmacokinetic profiles of the new ADCs (e.g., characterize them over longer time periods in vivo), and (2) determine whether the in vivo trends observed for BRD4-degrader conjugates extend to ADCs bearing chimeric degraders, which target other proteins.
    We concluded this phase of our studies by examining whether conjugation of chimeric BRD4 degraders to antibodies could potentially improve the thrombocytopenia risks associated with BRD4 inhibitors.(3,4) Other researchers have exploited low expression levels of various ubiquitin ligases in platelets to achieve reduced platelet toxicity for chimeric BCL-2/BCL-XL degraders relative to simple inhibitors.(38) As shown in Table 4, representative chimeric BRD4 degraders from this work were less potent when compared with the corresponding BRD4 inhibitors in an in vitro assessment of human megakaryocytopoiesis, which was known to correlate well with the in vivo thrombocytopenia potential (compare MKC IC50 of 1 with 2 and of 7 with 8, 9, and 13; see also Figure S15).(39) These potency differences may result from reduced cell permeability properties of the chimeric degraders relative to the simple inhibitors. In addition, as depicted in Table 4 and discussed elsewhere in this work, the chimeric degraders exhibited more potent antiproliferation activities against prostate cancer and AML cell lines with respect to the corresponding BRD4 inhibitors. As a result of these collective outcomes, the chimeric degraders displayed larger separations between in vitro megakaryocytopoiesis inhibition and cell-based anticancer activity relative to the tested BRD4 inhibitors (Table 4). These improvements were likely driven by the ability of the chimeric molecules to utilize the VHL ubiquitin ligase to degrade BRD4 in cancer cells but not in the various cell types involved in the megakaryocytopoiesis assessment. Consistent with this possibility, chimeric molecule 10, which contained a 4(S)-hydroxyproline moiety and thus did not efficiently engage the VHL protein (cf., Table 1), exhibited significantly smaller separations between anti-megakaryocytopoiesis and anticancer potencies relative to the corresponding 4(R)-hydroxyproline-containing analogue 9 (Table 4). However, we did not measure or otherwise quantitate VHL protein levels in the cells, which comprised the megakaryocytopoiesis assay to further substantiate the hypothesis.
    Table 4. Testing of Representative BRD4 Inhibitors, Chimeric Degraders, and Antibody–Drug Conjugates in In Vitro Assessments of Human Megakaryocytopoiesis and Anticancer Activitya
    classcmpd or CNJMKC IC50 (nM)aprostate IC50 (nM)bMKC/prostate ratiocAML IC50 (nM)dMKC/AML ratioe
    inhibitor1272730.10600.45
    inhibitor70.062.630.020.580.10
    chimeric degrader27987.60.904.3518.2
    chimeric degrader82917.91.61.9115.2
    chimeric degrader90.740.421.80.02529.6
    chimeric inhibitor104.025.50.161.642.44
    chimeric degrader131664.50.253.694.34
    ADCfSTEAP1–13a31026.911.5NANA
    ADCfCLL1–13a466NANA5.0991.6
    a

    In vitro inhibition of human megakaryocytopoiesis; see the Supporting Information and ref (39) for additional details.

    b

    Antiproliferation activity in prostate cancer cell lines (average of PC3-S1 and LNCaP IC50 values).

    c

    MKC IC50 divided by prostate IC50.

    d

    Antiproliferation activity in AML cell lines (average of HL-60 and EOL-1 IC50 values).

    e

    MKC IC50 divided by AML IC50.

    f

    IC50 values for ADCs are expressed in a “drug-equivalent” manner (i.e., reflects the concentration of the corresponding conjugated chimeric degrader payload) and are thus comparable to data for the unconjugated BRD4 degraders and inhibitors. Time point for all assays was 6 days. NA, not applicable.

    We also observed that conjugation of a representative chimeric BRD4 degrader to antibodies could further increase the separation between the undesired inhibition of megakaryocytopoiesis and anticancer effects in vitro. When normalized for payload loading (i.e., tested in “drug-equivalent” concentrations), both the STEAP1–13a and CLL1–13a conjugates exhibited significantly milder impacts in the megakaryocytopoiesis assay relative to the unconjugated chimeric degrader 13 (Figure 20 and Table 4). These outcomes presumably resulted from low or absent STEAP1 and CLL1 antigen expressions on the surfaces of the cells that comprised the megakaryocytopoiesis assessments, but we did not perform related antigen quantitation experiments to substantiate the possibility. The described example illustrates how potential differences in cytosolic ubiquitin ligase and surface antigen expressions can be combined to minimize undesired in vitro toxicities while maintaining potent cell-based anticancer impacts. However, additional studies that include dedicated in vivo toxicology assessments are needed to fully determine the generality and translatability of these initial findings.
    The preparations of chimeric degraders 9 and 10 as well as linker-drug 9b are described in the initial disclosure of our research activities.(17) The other unconjugated chimeric degraders described in this work and the corresponding linker-drugs required for ADC syntheses were generated by a variety of methods that are depicted in the following schemes. Hydrolysis of the ester moiety present in the known compound 6(17) under mild basic conditions provided the corresponding carboxylic acid 17 (Scheme 1). Subsequent coupling of this intermediate with methylamine using hexafluorophosphate azabenzotriazole tetramethyl uronium (HATU) then afforded compound 5. Alternatively, reduction of the ester contained in 6 with DIBAL-H gave alcohol 18, and this entity was then oxidized with Dess–Martin periodinane (DMP) to generate intermediate 19. The aldehyde group present in 19 was homologated to the corresponding alkyne (compound 7) by treatment with dimethyl (1-diazo-2-oxopropyl)phosphonate in methanol.
    The preparation of chimeric BRD4 degrader 8 and linker-drugs 8a and 8b is shown in Scheme 2. The known compound 20(40) was coupled to carboxylic acid 17 via a HATU-mediated process to give chimeric degrader 8 in a single step. Alternatively, the carbonate-containing entities 21 and 24 (see ref (16)) were independently deprotected under acidic conditions and the resulting amine salts (not shown) were coupled with the PEG spacer 22(16) to give the corresponding intermediates 23 and 25. Subsequent Boc deprotection of 23 and 25 followed by independent coupling of the resulting amine salts (not shown) with carboxylic acid 17 then, respectively, provided linker-drugs 8a and 8b after prep-HPLC purification.
    Scheme 3 depicts the syntheses of linker-drugs 9a and 9c. In independent experiments, the Boc groups present in the carbonate-containing entities 26 and 24 (see ref (16)) were removed under acidic conditions and the resulting amine salts (not shown) were coupled with the all-carbon spacer 27(41) to, respectively, generate the corresponding intermediates 28 and 29. A second round of acidic deprotections afforded the Boc-deprotected amines related to 28 and 29 (TFA salts, not shown), and these entitles were subsequently coupled with carboxylic acid 17 via HATU-mediated processes to, respectively, provide linker-drugs 9a and 9c.
    The preparation of pyrophosphate-containing linker-drug 9d is shown in Scheme 4. Carboxylic acid 17 was coupled to all-carbon spacer 30 (HCl salt, prepared from 27(41) in one step) to give intermediate 31. Separately, the known VHL-binding fragment 32(42) was protected as the corresponding Alloc derivative (33), and this entity was subsequently converted into the phosphite-containing intermediate 34. Activation/oxidation(43) of 34 as the corresponding imidazole-containing derivative (35) was followed by coupling with the known Fmoc-protected amino-phosphate 36(30b,44) to give pyrophosphate analogue 37. Removal of the Alloc group then provided amine 38, and this intermediate was coupled with 31 to afford the chimeric molecule 39. Fmoc deprotection of 39 followed by coupling of the resulting amine (not shown) with the commercially available reagent 40 then gave the linker-drug 9d.
    The methodologies employed to generate chimeric BRD4 degrader 11 and linker-drug 11a are illustrated in Scheme 5, while those utilized to prepare degrader 12 and linker-drug 12a are shown in Scheme 6. The Boc-containing intermediate 41(16) was deprotected under acidic conditions, and the resulting amine (TFA salt, 42) was coupled with carboxylic acid 17 to give the chimeric molecule 43 (Scheme 5). The Cbz moiety present in 43 was subsequently removed to provide chimeric degrader 11, and this entity was coupled with mixed carbonate 44(45) to afford linker-drug 11a (Scheme 5).
    In a related approach, Boc deprotection of compound 45(16) followed by coupling of the resulting amine (HCl salt, not shown) with the all-carbon spacer 27(40) gave the intermediate 46 (Scheme 6). A second acidic deprotection then afforded amine 47 (TFA salt), which was subsequently coupled to carboxylic acid 17 under HATU-mediated conditions to give the chimeric compound 48. Cleavage of the Cbz group present in 48 then afforded degrader 12, and this compound was condensed with mixed carbonate 44(45) to provide linker-drug 12a (Scheme 6).
    Scheme 7 shows the methods employed to prepare chimeric BRD4 degraders 13 and 14 as well as linker-drugs 13a, 14a, and 16. The Boc and tert-butyl moieties present in compound 49(16) were cleaved under acidic conditions to provide intermediate 50. This entity was coupled with the known VHL-binding fragment 32(42) to give 51. The Cbz group present in 51 was then removed via treatment with TMSI, and the resulting amine (not shown) was coupled with carboxylic acid 17 under HATU-mediated conditions to provide chimeric degrader 13. Derivatization of 13 via exposure to mixed carbonate 44(45) at slightly elevated temperatures subsequently afforded linker-drug 13a. Intermediate 50 was also combined with the epimeric VHL-binding fragment 52(17) to give product 53. Cbz deprotection and coupling of the resulting amine (not shown) with carboxylic acid 17 then converted 53 into chimeric degrader 14. Subsequent condensation of 14 with mixed carbonate 44(45) transformed the former entity into linker-drug 14a (Scheme 7). Finally, in a separate and independent transformation, linker-drug 16 was prepared by condensation of intermediate 51 with mixed carbonate 44.(45)
    The syntheses of chimeric degrader 15 and the corresponding linker-drug 15a are, respectively, depicted in Schemes 8 and 9. Removal of the Cbz protecting group from intermediate 54(16) provided the deprotected amine 55, and this entity was coupled with carboxylic acid 17 under HATU-mediated conditions to afford compound 56 (Scheme 8). Cleavage of the tert-butyl group present in 56 followed by coupling of the resulting carboxylic acid (not shown) with the known VHL-binding fragment 32(42) then gave chimeric degrader 15 (Scheme 8). Separately, the known Fmoc-protected l-citrulline-PAB-OH derivative 57(46) was converted to the corresponding bromide 58 (Scheme 9). This material was used to alkylate the phenol moiety present in intermediate 59 (prepared in one step via Boc-protection of amino-phenol 55) to give compound 60. Simultaneous cleavage of the Boc and tert-butyl groups contained in 60 was accomplished by exposure to acidic conditions, and the resulting amino acid (61) was coupled with carboxylic acid 17 to provide intermediate 62. This entity was subsequently coupled with the VHL-binding fragment 32(42) to afford the chimeric molecule 63. The Fmoc protecting group present in 63 was then removed under mild basic conditions, and the resulting amine (64) was condensed with 65(47) to give linker-drug 15a (Scheme 9).

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    This work details the second phase of our research activities aimed at optimizing the in vitro and in vivo bioactivities of chimeric BRD4-degrader antibody conjugates. It describes a shift in the focus of our conjugation efforts from chimeric molecules derived from compound 1 (JQ1, Figure 1)(16) to exploration of BRD4-degrading entities containing the more-potent BRD4-binding fragment 5 (Figure 2). As was performed in the first part of our research, we continued to thoroughly characterize the biological properties of the newly created chimeric degraders in the unconjugated form using assessments of BRD4 and VHL-binding, BRD4/VHL ternary complex formation, and IAM-based cell permeability in addition to cellular BRD4 degradation and antiproliferation profiling. These characterizations collectively demonstrated that BRD4 degraders derived from 5 were significantly more potent in cell-based assays relative to the chimeric molecules we studied in the initial phase of our research (e.g., compounds 2 and 3, Figure 1). Importantly, the cell-based activities of the new chimeric entities described in this work were closer to the range of potencies typically associated with successful cytotoxic ADC payloads (i.e., low nanomolar to picomolar antiproliferation IC50 values).
    We also continued to target the synthesis of ADCs with drug/antibody ratios of 6 (DAR6, “high-DAR” conjugates) in an effort to maximize the amounts of attached chimeric degraders delivered to the interior of cells. In contrast to the first part of our research, we periodically encountered challenges in achieving the desired DAR6 antibody loadings due to extensive aggregation issues that were observed following attachment of certain highly lipophilic linker-drugs (e.g., 9 and 12) to the antibodies. These unwanted outcomes were highly sensitive to subtle changes in the antibody linker composition as well as the antigen targeted by the employed mAbs. The results highlighted the need for continued research in the antibody–drug conjugate field that seeks to identify linker and/or conjugation technologies that routinely enable the generation of high-DAR ADCs from lipophilic payloads.(48)
    In spite of these challenges, multiple examples of cell-active DAR6 STEAP1-targeting BRD4-degrader conjugates were identified during the course of the research described in this work. Many of these entities exhibited large separations between their potent PC3-S1 BRD4 degradation and antiproliferation properties and the in vitro activities displayed by the corresponding CLL1-targeting control conjugates. These outcomes were consistent with antigen-dependent, antibody-mediated delivery of the chimeric degrader molecules to the targeted STEAP1-expressing prostate cancer cells. Alternatively, several conjugates directed at the CLL1 antigen were employed to selectively deliver several representative chimeric degrader payloads (e.g., compounds 8 and 13) to HL-60 AML cells in an antigen-dependent manner. The collective in vitro results illustrated the ability to direct the delivery of the chimeric molecules to cancer cells of interest solely by proper mAb antigen selection without having to re-engineer the design of the associated antibody linkers.
    Very encouragingly, the favorable cell culture outcomes translated into the in vivo realm where examples of strong, antigen-dependent antitumor activity were achieved in both prostate cancer and AML xenograft models. Importantly, the in vivo antitumor efficacy was demonstrated with structurally diverse conjugates that employed a peptidomimetic protease-cleavable or a disulfide-containing glutathione-cleavable linker and distinct chimeric BRD4-degrader payloads (compounds 8 and 13). Equally important, control experiments clearly demonstrated that the in vivo activity of the CLL1–13a conjugate was associated with the delivery of a potent BRD4 protein degrader (as opposed to a potent BRD4 and/or VHL inhibitor). When combined with the initial disclosure of in vivo activity associated with conjugates derived from compound 9,(17) the collective results suggest that antibody conjugation of BRD4-targeted chimeric degraders can serve as a general means of enabling such modalities to achieve meaningful in vivo efficacy outcomes. Additional experiments are required to determine whether in vivo-active conjugates can be constructed using chimeric molecules that degrade proteins other than BRD4. However, we believe that the results described in this work and the related preceding paper clearly establish antibody-mediated delivery as an option that should strongly be considered during the preclinical exploration of chimeric degrader molecules.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Chemistry Methods

    Unless otherwise indicated, all reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Moisture- or oxygen-sensitive reactions were conducted under an atmosphere of argon or nitrogen gas. Unless otherwise stated, 1H NMR spectra were recorded at 300 or 400 MHz using Varian or Bruker instruments operating at the indicated frequencies. Chemical shifts are expressed in ppm (δ) relative to an internal standard; tetramethylsilane (ppm = 0.00). The following abbreviations are used: br, broad signal; s, singlet; d, doublet; dd, doublet of doublets; t, triplet; q, quartet; p, pentet; m, multiplet. Purification by silica gel chromatography was carried out using Biotage systems with prepacked cartridges. Analytical LCMS methods are provided in the Supporting Information (Table S8). Chemical purities were ≥95% for all final compounds as assessed by LCMS analysis at UV 220 and 254 nm.

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxylic Acid (17)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 6(17) (30 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 4:1:1 THF:MeOH:H2O (6.0 mL) was added LiOH·H2O (12 mg, 0.29 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then was diluted with water (10 mL). The resulting mixture was washed with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL), and the aqueous layer was acidified with HCl (1.0 M) to pH = 4.0. This layer was then extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL), and the combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated to afford compound 17 (25 mg, 86%) as a yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.73 min, m/z = 501.0 [M + H]+.

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-N,10-dimethyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (5)

    Compound 6 (40 mg, 0.08 mmol) was added to a solution of MeNH2·HCl (11 mg, 0.16 mmol), HATU (46 mg, 0.12 mmol), and DIEA (230 mg, 1.79 mmol) in DMF (10 mL) at 23 °C. The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated. The residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 20–50%/0.225% FA in H2O) to give compound 5 (33 mg, 81%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.61 min, m/z = 514.0 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.94 (brs, 1H), 8.42–8.34 (m, 1H), 8.08 (d, J = 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.76 (s, 1H), 7.66–7.58 (m, 1H), 7.31–7.25 (m, 2H), 5.95 (brs, 1H), 5.22 (brs, 1H), 4.63 (brs, 1H), 4.25 (brs, 1H), 3.63 (s, 3H), 2.91 (s, 3H), 2.69 (d, J = 4.4 Hz, 3H).

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-6-(hydroxymethyl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-1,3,4,10-tetrahydro-11H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulen-11-one (18)

    To a −78 °C solution of compound 6(17) (30 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 1,2-dichloroethane (20 mL) was added a solution of DIBAL-H in toluene (1.0 M, 0.23 mL, 0.23 mmol). The reaction solution was stirred at −78 °C for 2 h and then quenched with H2O (10 mL). The resulting mixture was extracted with DCM (2 × 30 mL), and the combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated to afford the crude compound 18 (27 mg, 95%) as a light oil. This material was used in the next step without additional purification. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.75 min, m/z = 487.1 [M + H]+.

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carbaldehyde (19)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 18 (27 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 1,2-dichloroethane (10 mL) was added DMP (70 mg, 0.17 mmol). The reaction was stirred at 23 °C for 12 h; then, H2O (10 mL) was added. The resulting mixture was extracted with DCM (2 × 30 mL), and the combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. Purification of the residue by prep-TLC (15% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.3) then provided compound 19 (20 mg, 74%) as a yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.80 min, m/z = 485.1 [M + H]+.

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-6-ethynyl-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-1,3,4,10-tetrahydro-11H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulen-11-one (7)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 19 (12 mg, 0.02 mmol) in MeOH (6 mL) were added K2CO3 (12 mg, 0.09 mmol) and dimethyl (1-diazo-2-oxopropyl)phosphonate (12 mg, 0.06 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 12 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting residue was partitioned between H2O (10 mL) and EtOAc (2 × 20 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 36–66%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 7 (2.8 mg, 24%) as an off-white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.77 min, m/z = 503.1 [M + Na]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.94 (brs, 1H), 8.07 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.94 (s, 1H), 7.72 (s, 1H), 7.67–7.63 (m, 1H), 7.28–7.25 (m, 2H), 5.90 (brs, 1H), 4.63 (brs, 2H), 4.51 (s, 1H), 4.25 (brs, 1H), 3.63 (s, 3H), 3.02 (s, 3H).

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-N-((S)-13-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidine-1-carbonyl)-14,14-dimethyl-11-oxo-3,6,9-trioxa-12-azapentadecyl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (8)

    A mixture of compound 20(40) (53 mg, 0.07 mmol), compound 17 (30 mg, 0.06 mmol), Et3N (18 mg, 0.18 mmol), and HATU (34 mg, 0.09 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h. The mixture was then directly purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 15–45%/0.225% FA in H2O) to give compound 8 (20 mg, 31%) as an off-white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.77 min, m/z =1102.6 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.88 (s, 1H), 8.94 (s, 1H), 8.58–8.55 (m, 1H), 8.46–8.44 (m, 1H), 8.03 (s, 1H), 7.89 (s, 1H), 7.73 (s, 1H), 7.59–7.54 (m, 1H), 7.46–7.29 (m, 5H), 7.26–7.24 (m, 2H), 5.90 (brs, 1H), 5.14 (brs, 1H), 4.54–4.52 (m, 2H), 4.46–4.29 (m, 3H), 4.27–4.15 (m, 1H), 4.09–4.03 (m, 1 H), 3.96–3.87 (m, 2H), 3.61–3.47 (m, 14H), 2.87 (s, 3H), 2.40 (s, 3H), 2.02–2.00 (m, 1H), 1.90–1.84 (m, 1H), 1.29–1.08 (m, 1H), 0.91 (s, 9H).

    S-(1-(((((3R,5S)-1-((S)-18-(tert-Butyl)-2,2-dimethyl-4,16-dioxo-3,8,11,14-tetraoxa-5,17-diazanonadecan-19-oyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)carbonyl)oxy)-2-methylpropan-2-yl) Methanesulfonothioate (23)

    TFA (0.1 mL) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 21(16) (107 mg, 0.14 mmol) in HFIP (1.9 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo to give the corresponding crude TFA salt (not shown, 109 mg, 100%) as a colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.63 min, m/z = 641.0 [M + H]+. Separately, DIEA (50 mg, 0.37 mmol) was added to a solution of compound 22(16) (30 mg, 0.10 mmol) and HATU (42 mg, 0.11 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) at 23 °C. The mixture was stirred at that temperature for 10 min; then, a portion of the crude TFA salt obtained from compound 21 (56 mg, 0.07 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (5% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.5) to afford compound 23 (65 mg, 82%) as a yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.85 min, m/z = 952.3 [M + Na]+.

    S-(1-(((((3R,5S)-1-((S)-15-(tert-Butyl)-1-(4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulen-6-yl)-1,13-dioxo-5,8,11-trioxa-2,14-diazahexadecan-16-oyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)carbonyl)oxy)-2-methylpropan-2-yl) Methanesulfonothioate (8a)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 23 (65 mg, 0.06 mmol) in HFIP (6.0 mL) was added TFA (0.3 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude deprotected amine (TFA salt, not shown, 57 mg, 100%) as a yellow oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.72 min, m/z = 830.3 [M + H]+. Separately, DIEA (23 mg, 0.17 mmol) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 17 (20 mg, 0.04 mmol) and HATU (20 mg, 0.05 mmol) in DMF (5 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min, and a portion of the crude TFA salt obtained from compound 23 (33 mg, 0.03 mmol) was then added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 41–71%/0.225% FA in H2O) to give compound 8a (22 mg, 42%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.82 min, m/z = 1313.6 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.91 (s, 1H), 8.97 (s, 1H), 8.65 (brs, 1H), 8.48 (brs, 1H), 8.06 (s, 1H), 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.76 (s, 1H), 7.62–7.57 (m, 1H), 7.45–7.39 (m, 5H), 7.28 (brs, 2H), 5.95 (br, 1H), 5.26–5.17 (m, 2H), 4.45–4.26 (m, 7H), 4.07–3.86 (m, 4H), 3.62 (brs, 5H), 3.53 (brs, 10H), 2.90 (s, 3H), 2.43–2.33 (m, 7H), 2.15–1.99 (m, 1H), 1.49 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, 6H), 1.23 (brs, 1H), 0.91 (s, 9H).

    S-(3-(((((3R,5S)-1-((S)-18-(tert-Butyl)-2,2-dimethyl-4,16-dioxo-3,8,11,14-tetraoxa-5,17-diazanonadecan-19-oyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)carbonyl)oxy)butan-2-yl) Methanesulfonothioate (25)

    TFA (0.3 mL) was added to a solution of compound 24(16) (90 mg, 0.12 mmol) in HFIP (6.0 mL) at 23 °C. The reaction solution was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude deprotected amine (TFA salt, not shown, 90 mg, 98%) as a colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.74 min, m/z = 641.1 [M + H]+. Separately, DIEA (77 mg, 0.60 mmol) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 22(16) (55 mg, 0.18 mmol) and HATU (91 mg, 0.24 mmol) in DMF (6 mL). The reaction solution was stirred at 23 °C for 15 min; then, the crude amine TFA salt obtained from compound 24 (90 mg, 0.12 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 0.5 h and then concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (10% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.7) to afford compound 25 (100 mg, 83%) as a white solid. LCMS (10–80, AB, 7.0 min): RT = 4.03 min, m/z = 952.3 [M + Na]+.

    S-(3-(((((3R,5S)-1-((S)-15-(tert-Butyl)-1-(4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulen-6-yl)-1,13-dioxo-5,8,11-trioxa-2,14-diazahexadecan-16-oyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)carbonyl)oxy)butan-2-yl) Methanesulfonothioate (8b)

    To a solution of compound 25 (90 mg, 0.10 mmol) in HFIP (7.0 mL) was added TFA (0.35 mL) at 23 °C. The reaction solution was stirred at that temperature for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude deprotected amine (TFA salt, not shown, 90 mg, 99%) as a colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.76 min, m/z = 830.5 [M + H]+. Separately, DIEA (21 mg, 0.16 mmol) and HATU (18 mg, 0.05 mmol) were added sequentially to a 23 °C solution of compound 17 (20 mg, 0.04 mmol) in DMF (4 mL). The reaction solution was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min; then, a portion of the crude amine TFA salt obtained from compound 25 (45 mg, 0.05 mmol) was added. The resulting solution was stirred at 23 °C for an additional 1 h and then directly purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 36–66%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 8b (15 mg, 29%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.84 min, m/z = 1334.2 [M + Na]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.87 (s, 1H), 7.94 (s, 1H), 7.88 (s, 1H), 7.69 (s, 2H), 7.62–7.58 (m, 1H), 7.43–7.35 (m, 3H), 7.25–7.22 (m, 2H), 5.29 (s, 1H), 4.62–4.51 (m, 4H), 4.34–4.22 (m, 4H), 4.04–3.92 (m, 4H), 3.71–3.64 (m, 11H), 3.51–3.49 (m, 2H), 3.43–3.38 (m, 3H), 2.98 (s, 3H), 2.44 (s, 4H), 2.29–2.26 (m, 2H), 1.46–1.43 (m, 2H), 1.38–1.25 (m, 4H), 1.00 (s, 9H).

    S-((R)-1-(((((3R,5S)-1-((S)-2-(11-((tert-Butoxycarbonyl)amino)undecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)carbonyl)oxy)propan-2-yl) Methanesulfonothioate (28)

    TFA (0.1 mL) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 26(16) (86 mg, 0.12 mmol) in HFIP (2 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at that temperature for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo to give the crude deprotected amine (TFA salt, not shown, 76 mg, 87%) as a colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.61 min, m/z = 627.0 [M + H]+. Separately, a mixture of compound 27(41) (27 mg, 0.09 mmol), DIEA (26 mg, 0.20 mmol), and HATU (33 mg, 0.09 mmol) was stirred in DMF (5 mL) at 23 °C for 10 min. A portion of the crude TFA salt obtained from compound 26 (50 mg, 0.07 mmol) was then added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h; then, the mixture was concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel eluting with 0–10% MeOH in DCM to give compound 28 (44 mg, 72%) as a colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 1.05 min, m/z = 932.4 [M + Na]+.

    S-((R)-1-(((((3R,5S)-1-((S)-2-(11-(4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)undecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)carbonyl)oxy)propan-2-yl) Methanesulfonothioate (9a)

    To a solution of compound 28 (44 mg, 0.05 mmol) in HFIP (2 mL) at 23 °C was added TFA (0.1 mL). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo to give the crude deprotected amine (TFA salt, not shown, 44 mg, 99%) as a colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.69 min, m/z = 810.3 [M + H]+. Separately, a 23 °C solution of compound 17 (18 mg, 0.04 mmol), DIEA (15 mg, 0.12 mmol), and HATU (14 mg, 0.04 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) was stirred for 10 min. A portion of the crude TFA salt obtained from compound 28 (22 mg, 0.02 mmol) was then added, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h. The mixture was subsequently purified directly by prep-HPLC (MeCN 43–73%/0.225% FA in H2O) to give compound 9a (19 mg, 62%) as a white solid. LCMS (10–80, AB, 7.0 min): RT = 4.44 min, m/z = 1314.6 [M + Na]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.89 (brs, 1H), 8.95 (s, 1H), 8.58 (brs, 1H), 8.37 (brs, 1H), 8.03 (s, 1H), 7.88–7.84 (m, 2H), 7.72 (brs, 1H), 7.59–7.37 (m, 2H), 7.37–7.35 (s, 3H), 7.23 (brs, 2H), 5.91 (br, 2H), 5.19 (s, 2H), 4.39–4.34 (m, 8H), 4.28–4.22 (m, 1H), 3.82–3.80 (m, 2H), 3.59 (s, 3H), 3.53 (s, 3H), 3.10 (s, 1H), 2.87 (s, 4H), 2.63 (s, 1H), 2.40 (s, 3H), 2.30–2.20 (m, 2H), 2.19–2.05 (m, 3H), 1.38–1.36 (m, 6H), 0.91 (m, 10H), 0.87 (s, 9H).

    S-(3-(((((3R,5S)-1-((S)-2-(11-((tert-Butoxycarbonyl)amino)undecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)carbonyl)oxy)butan-2-yl) Methanesulfonothioate (29)

    TFA (0.2 mL) was added to a solution of compound 24(16) (100 mg, 0.13 mmol) in HFIP (4.0 mL) at 23 °C, and the resulting mixture was stirred at that temperature for 1 h. The solution was then concentrated in vacuo to remove the volatiles to afford the crude deprotected amine (TFA salt, not shown, 100 mg, 98%) as a colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.72 min, m/z = 641.1 [M + H]+. Separately, HATU (61 mg, 0.16 mmol) and DIEA (69 mg, 0.53 mmol) were added sequentially to a solution of compound 27(41) (40 mg, 0.13 mmol) in DCM (10 mL) at 23 °C. The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 15 min; then, a solution of crude TFA salt obtained from compound 24 (100 mg, 0.13 mmol) in DCM (5 mL) was added. The resulting reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for an additional 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (10% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.5) to afford compound 29 (85 mg, 61%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.96 min, m/z = 946.3 [M + Na]+.

    S-(3-(((((3R,5S)-1-((S)-2-(11-(4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)undecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)carbonyl)oxy)butan-2-yl) Methanesulfonothioate (9c)

    TFA (0.2 mL) was added to a solution of compound 29 (85 mg, 0.09 mmol) in HFIP (4.0 mL) at 23 °C, and the resulting mixture was stirred at that temperature for 1 h. The solution was subsequently concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude deprotected amine (TFA salt, not shown, 86 mg, 100%) as a crude colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.78 min, m/z = 824.4 [M + H]+. To a 23 °C solution of compound 17 (20 mg, 0.04 mmol) in DMF (4 mL) were added HATU (20 mg, 0.05 mmol) and DIEA (26 mg, 0.20 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min; then, a portion of the crude TFA salt obtained from compound 29 (49 mg, 0.05 mmol) was added. The resulting reaction solution was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then directly purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 5–80%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 9c (23 mg, 43%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.89 min, m/z = 1329.1 [M + Na]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.93 (s, 1H), 8.98 (s, 1H), 8.62–8.60 (m, 1H), 8.41–8.39 (m, 1H), 8.06 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.91–7.87 (m, 2H), 7.75 (s, 1H), 7.63–7.57 (m, 2H), 7.43–7.37 (m, 3H), 7.27–7.26 (m, 2H), 5.22–5.19 (m, 2H), 4.98–4.94 (m, 2H), 4.47–4.35 (m, 4H), 4.27–4.09 (m, 4H), 3.84–3.80 (m, 2H), 3.75–3.70 (m, 2H), 3.62 (s, 3H), 3.54 (d, J = 2.8 Hz, 3H), 3.13 (brs, 3H), 2.90 (s, 3H), 2.67 (brs, 1H), 2.44 (s, 3H), 2.33–2.09 (m, 3H), 1.45–1.32 (m, 10H), 1.21 (s, 8H), 0.94 (s, 9H).

    11-Aminoundecanoic Acid (30)

    Compound 27(41) (30 mg, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in 4 M HCl in 1,4-dioxane (2 mL) at 23 °C, and the resulting mixture was stirred at that temperature for 1 h. The mixture was then concentrated under reduced pressure to give the crude compound 30 (HCl salt, 24 mg, 100%) as a gray solid. This material was used without additional purification in the preparation of compound 31 below.

    11-(4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)undecanoic Acid (31)

    A solution of compound 17 (25 mg, 0.05 mmol), DIEA (19 mg, 0.15 mmol), and HATU (23 mg, 0.06 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h. The crude compound 30 (HCl salt, 18 mg, 0.07 mmol) was then added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (12% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.4) to give compound 31 (34 mg, 100%) as a gray solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.82 min, m/z = 684.3 [M + H]+.

    Allyl ((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-Hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (33)

    Allyl chloroformate (485 mg, 4.02 mmol) was added to a 0 °C mixture of compound 32(42) (1.65 g, 3.83 mmol) and NaHCO3 (1.61 g, 19.2 mmol) in 1:1 THF:H2O (34 mL). The resulting mixture was allowed to warm to 25 °C and stirred at that temperature for 12 h. After diluting with water (50 mL), the reaction mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 50 mL), and the combined organic layers were washed with brine (50 mL), dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel eluting with 0–3% MeOH in DCM to give compound 33 (1.60 g, 81%) as a gray solid. LCMS (10–80, AB, 7.0 min): RT = 2.57 min, m/z = 537.1 [M + Na]+.

    Allyl ((2S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-((Hydroxyhydrophosphoryl)oxy)-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (34)

    To a solution of compound 33 (450 mg, 0.87 mmol) in THF (5 mL) at −78 °C was added a solution of PCl3 (500 mg, 3.64 mmol) in THF (2 mL) followed by a solution of Et3N (0.73 mL, 5.25 mmol) in THF (2 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at −78 °C for 20 min and then allowed to warm to 23 °C. After stirring at 23 °C for 12 h, the reaction was quenched by sequential addition of H2O (2 mL) and saturated aqueous NaHCO3 (5 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min and then acidified with 1 N HCl to pH = 3 and concentrated. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (12% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.4) to afford the compound 34 (450 mg, 89% yield) as a colorless solid. LCMS (0–60, CD, 3.0 min): RT = 1.42 min, m/z = 579.2 [M + H]+.

    Allyl ((2S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-((Hydroxy(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phosphoryl)oxy)-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (35)

    1-(Trimethylsilyl)-1H-imidazole (436 mg, 3.11 mmol) was added to a solution of compound 34 (450 mg, 0.78 mmol), and Et3N (0.43 mL, 3.11 mmol) in 1:1 MeCN:CCl4 (8 mL) was added at 23 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at that temperature for 40 min; then, MeOH (0.1 mL) was added, and stirring was continued for an additional 10 min. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure, and the remaining solid was suspended in 5:1 MTBE:EtOAc (3 mL) and collected by filtration. The white solid thus obtained was washed with MTBE (3 mL) to afford compound 35 (450 mg, 90%). LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.73 min, m/z = 645.3 [M + H]+.

    Allyl ((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-((3-(2-((((9H-Fluoren-9-yl)methoxy)carbonyl)amino)ethoxy)-1,1,3,3-tetraoxo-1l6,3l6-diphosphoxaneyl)oxy)-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)carbamate (37)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 35 (450 mg, 0.70 mmol) and compound 36(30b,44) (355 mg, 0.98 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) was added ZnCl2 (1.0 M in THF, 6.98 mL, 6.98 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 12 h and then quenched by the addition of 1 N HCl (5 mL). The volatiles were removed under reduced pressure, and the residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 22–42%/10 mM NH4HCO3 in H2O) to afford compound 37 (250 mg, 38%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 1.75 min, m/z = 940.3 [M + H]+.

    (9H-Fluoren-9-yl)methyl (2-((3-(((3R,5S)-1-((S)-2-Amino-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)-1,1,3,3-tetraoxo-1l6,3l6-diphosphoxaneyl)oxy)ethyl)carbamate (38)

    To a solution of compound 37 (100 mg, 0.11 mmol) and 1,3-dimethylbarbituric acid (83 mg, 0.53 mmol) in DCM (1 mL) and MeOH (0.20 mL) was added Pd(PPh3)4 (25 mg, 0.02 mmol) at 23 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then concentrated in vacuo. The resulting residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 18–48%/10 mM NH4HCO3 in H2O) to afford compound 38 (55 mg, 61%) as a white solid. LCMS (0–60, CD, 3.0 min): RT = 1.44 min, m/z = 856.1 [M + H]+.

    (9H-Fluoren-9-yl)methyl (2-((3-(((3R,5S)-1-((S)-2-(11-(4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)undecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-5-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-3-yl)oxy)-1,1,3,3-tetraoxo-1l6,3l6-diphosphoxaneyl)oxy)ethyl)carbamate (39)

    A solution of compound 31 (120 mg, 0.18 mmol), DIEA (8.0 mg, 0.06 mmol), and HATU (22 mg, 0.06 mmol) in anhydrous DMF (2 mL) was stirred at 23 °C for 20 min. Compound 38 (50 mg, 0.06 mmol) was then added, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was subsequently filtered, and the filtrate was directly purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 27–57%/0.05% NH4OH in H2O) to afford compound 39 (40 mg, 45%) as a white solid. LCMS (0–60, CD, 3.0 min): RT =1.97 min, m/z = 761.3 [M/2 + H]+.

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-N-(11-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-((3-(2-(6-(2,5-dioxo-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrrol-1-yl)hexanamido)ethoxy)-1,1,3,3-tetraoxo-1l6,3l6-diphosphoxaneyl)oxy)-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-11-oxoundecyl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (9d)

    Piperidine (11 mg, 0.13 mmol) was added to a solution of compound 39 (40 mg, 0.03 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) at 23 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then filtered. The filtrate was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 23–53%/10 mM NH4HCO3 in H2O) to afford the deprotected amine (not shown, 20 mg, 59% yield) as a white solid. LCMS (0–60, CD, 3.0 min): RT = 1.73 min, m/z = 650.3 [M/2 + H]+. A portion of this material (10 mg, 0.01 mmol) was added to a solution of compound 40 (6.0 mg, 0.02 mmol) and DIEA (2.0 mg, 0.02 mmol) in DMF (1 mL) at 23 °C. The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 6 h and then filtered. The filtrate was directly purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 25–55%/0.1% TFA in H2O) to afford compound 9d (2.7 mg, 24%) as a white solid. LCMS (10–80, AB, 7.0 min): RT = 3.72 min, m/z = 746.8 [M/2 + H]+. HRMS (ESI, 0-95_1_4min_CD): m/z = 1492.51 [M + 1]+.

    Benzyl 4-(2-(((2S,4R)-1-((S)-14-Amino-2-(tert-butyl)-4-oxo-6,9,12-trioxa-3-azatetradecanoyl)-4-hydroxypyrrolidine-2-carboxamido)methyl)-5-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)phenoxy)piperidine-1-carboxylate (42)

    A solution of compound 41 (150 mg, 0.16 mmol) in 1:3 TFA:DCM (4 mL) was stirred at 23 °C for 30 min. The reaction mixture was then concentrated to give the crude Boc-deprotected amine (TFA salt, 130 mg, 97%) as a colorless oil. This material was used in the next step without additional purification. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.78 min, m/z = 875.1 [M + Na]+.

    Benzyl 4-(2-(((2S,4R)-1-((S)-15-(tert-Butyl)-1-(4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulen-6-yl)-1,13-dioxo-5,8,11-trioxa-2,14-diazahexadecan-16-oyl)-4-hydroxypyrrolidine-2-carboxamido)methyl)-5-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)phenoxy)piperidine-1-carboxylate (43)

    DIEA (78 mg, 0.60 mmol) and HATU (68 mg, 0.18 mmol) were sequentially added to a 23 °C solution of compound 17 (75 mg, 0.15 mmol) in DMF (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min; then, crude compound 42 (145 mg, 0.15 mmol) was added. The resulting solution was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (10% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.5) to afford compound 43 (198 mg, 98%) as a pale-yellow oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.85 min, m/z = 1358.0 [M + Na]+.

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-N-((S)-13-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)-2-(piperidin-4-yloxy)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidine-1-carbonyl)-14,14-dimethyl-11-oxo-3,6,9-trioxa-12-azapentadecyl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (11)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 43 (160 mg, 0.12 mmol) in DCM (4 mL) was added TMSI (240 mg, 1.2 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h; then, MeOH (20 mL) was added, and stirring was continued at 23 °C for an additional 10 min. The mixture was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 0–40%/0.1% HCl in H2O) to afford compound 11 (42 mg, 27%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.77 min, m/z = 1201.6 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.86 (s, 1H), 8.53 (s, 1H), 7.94 (s, 1H), 7.87 (d, J = 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (s, 1H), 7.47 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.36 (s, 1H), 7.23–7.21 (m, 2H), 7.05–7.00 (m, 2H), 4.88 (brs, 2H), 4.69 (s, 1H), 4.60–4.49 (m, 5H), 4.38–4.34 (m, 1H), 4.01 (d, J = 4.0 Hz, 2H), 3.88–3.79 (m, 2H), 3.70–3.63 (m, 13 H), 3.51–3.44 (m, 4 H), 3.31–3.24 (m, 2H), 2.99 (s, 3H), 2.46 (s, 3H), 2.21–2.03 (s, 6H), 1.02 (s, 9H).

    4-((S)-2-(1-((5-(2,5-Dioxo-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrrol-1-yl)pentyl)carbamoyl)cyclobutane-1-carboxamido)-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl 4-(2-(((2S,4R)-1-((S)-15-(tert-Butyl)-1-(4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulen-6-yl)-1,13-dioxo-5,8,11-trioxa-2,14-diazahexadecan-16-oyl)-4-hydroxypyrrolidine-2-carboxamido)methyl)-5-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)phenoxy)piperidine-1-carboxylate (11a)

    DIEA (10 mg, 0.08 mmol) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 11 (25 mg, 0.02 mmol) and compound 44(45) in DMF (2 mL). The reaction solution was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then directly purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 35–65%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 11a (17 mg, 45%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.80 min, m/z = 900.4 [M/2 + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.85 (s, 1H), 7.93 (s, 1H), 7.87 (d, J = 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (s, 1H), 7.62–7.59 (m, 3H), 7.43 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.35 (s, 1H), 7.30 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.26 (s, 1H), 7.21 (s, 1H), 7.01–6.94 (m, 1H), 6.75 (s, 2H), 5.06 (brs, 1H), 4.89–4.67 (m, 12H), 4.65–4.61 (m, 1H), 4.01 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 2H), 3.71–3.61 (m, 15H), 3.49–3.42 (m, 5H), 3.31–3.22 (m, 3H), 3.25–3.21 (m, 4H), 3.16–3.13 (m, 2H), 2.97 (s, 3H), 2.56–2.51 (m, 2H), 2.45 (s, 3H), 1.94–1.92 (m, 3H), 1.78–1.74 (m, 2H), 1.55–1.51 (m, 6H), 1.28–1.26 (m, 4H), 1.00 (s, 9H).

    Benzyl 4-(2-(((2S,4R)-1-((S)-2-(11-((tert-Butoxycarbonyl)amino)undecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-4-hydroxypyrrolidine-2-carboxamido)methyl)-5-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)phenoxy)piperidine-1-carboxylate (46)

    A solution of compound 45(16) (200 mg, 0.26 mmol) in 4.0 M HCl in EtOAc (2 mL) was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h. The mixture was concentrated under reduced pressure to give the crude deprotected amine (HCl salt, not shown, 183 mg, 100%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.77 min, m/z = 664.1 [M + H]+. Separately, HATU (199 mg, 0.52 mmol) and DIEA (101 mg, 0.78 mmol) were sequentially added to a solution of compound 27(41) (95 mg, 0.31 mmol) in DMF (10 mL) at 23 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at that temperature for 10 min; then, the crude amine salt obtained from compound 45 (183 mg, 0.26 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 65–95%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 46 (90 mg, 36% yield) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.97 min, m/z = 969.4 [M + Na]+.

    Benzyl 4-(2-(((2S,4R)-1-((S)-2-(11-Aminoundecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-4-hydroxypyrrolidine-2-carboxamido)methyl)-5-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)phenoxy)piperidine-1-carboxylate (47)

    TFA (0.15 mL) was added to a solution of compound 46 (100 mg, 0.11 mmol) in HFIP (2.85 mL) at 23 °C. The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated to give the crude compound 47 (TFA salt, 101 mg, 100%). This material was used in the next step without additional purification. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.85 min, m/z = 847.5 [M + H]+.

    Benzyl 4-(2-(((2S,4R)-1-((S)-2-(11-(4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)undecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-4-hydroxypyrrolidine-2-carboxamido)methyl)-5-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)phenoxy)piperidine-1-carboxylate (48)

    DIEA (39 mg, 0.30 mmol) was added to a solution of compound 17 (30 mg, 0.06 mmol) and HATU (25 mg, 0.07 mmol) in DMF (3.0 mL) at 23 °C. The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min; then, the crude compound 47 (63 mg, 0.07 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for an additional 1 h, after which it was concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 60–90%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 48 (18 mg, 23%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 1.00 min, m/z = 1329.1 [M + H]+.

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-N-(11-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)-2-(piperidin-4-yloxy)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-11-oxoundecyl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (12)

    TMSI (1.00 mL, 0.06 mmol) was added to a solution of compound 48 (16 mg, 0.01 mmol) in DCM (4.0 mL) at 23 °C, and the resulting mixture was stirred at that temperature for 0.5 h. MeOH (2.0 mL) and aqueous 1 M HCl (2.00 mL) were then added sequentially, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 15 min. The volatiles were removed in vacuo, and the residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 30–50%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 12 (10 mg, 70%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.71 min, m/z = 1195.6 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.97 (s, 1H), 8.43–8.40 (m, 3H), 8.06 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 7.91 (s, 1H), 7.87–7.85 (m, 1H), 7.75 (s, 1H), 7.60–7.57 (m, 1H), 7.46 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.26 (d, J = 3.2 Hz, 2H), 7.06 (s, 1H), 6.90 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 5.92 (br, 1H), 5.18 (br, 2H), 4.68 (br, 1H), 4.53 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 1H), 4.45 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 4.38–4.34 (m, 2H), 4.17–4.14 (m, 2H), 3.65 (s, 3H), 3.62 (s, 5H), 3.13–3.08 (m, 3H), 2.90 (s, 3H), 2.84 (br, 3H), 2.44 (s, 3H), 2.27–2.22 (m, 1H), 2.12–1.94 (m, 4H), 1.75–1.68 (m, 2H), 1.44 (br, 4H), 1.21 (br, 14H), 0.91 (s, 9H).

    4-((S)-2-(1-((5-(2,5-Dioxo-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrrol-1-yl)pentyl)carbamoyl)cyclobutane-1-carboxamido)-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl 4-(2-(((2S,4R)-1-((S)-2-(11-(4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)undecanamido)-3,3-dimethylbutanoyl)-4-hydroxypyrrolidine-2-carboxamido)methyl)-5-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)phenoxy)piperidine-1-carboxylate (12a)

    DIEA (1.7 mg, 0.01 mmol) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 44(45) (3.7 mg, 0.01 mmol) and compound 12 (4.0 mg, 0.0033 mmol) in DMF (3.0 mL). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then directly purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 38–68%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 12a (2.5 mg, 41%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.76 min, m/z = 896.8 [M/2 + H]+.

    2-(3-Amino-5-(2-(((benzyloxy)carbonyl)amino)ethoxy)phenethoxy)acetic Acid (50)

    TFA (2.0 mL) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 49(16) (273 mg, 0.50 mmol) in DCM (2 mL), and the mixture was stirred at that temperature for 1 h. The mixture was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 21–51%/0.225% FA in H2O) to give compound 50 (FA salt, 100 mg, 40%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.72 min, m/z = 389.3 [M + H]+.

    Benzyl (2-(3-Amino-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenoxy)ethyl)carbamate (51)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 32(42) (256 mg, 0.59 mmol), compound 50 (110 mg, 0.28 mmol), and HATU (119 mg, 0.31 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) was added DIEA (183 mg, 1.42 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (10% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.5) to give compound 51 (120 mg, 53%) as a yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.86 min, m/z = 823.3 [M + Na]+.

    N-(2-(3-Amino-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenoxy)ethyl)-4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (13)

    TMSI (100 mg, 0.50 mmol) was added to a solution of compound 51 (80 mg, 0.10 mmol) in DCM (5 mL) at 23 °C, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h. The volatiles were removed in vacuo, and the resulting residue was triturated with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL) to afford the crude deprotected amine (not shown, 90 mg, 98%) as a yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.66 min, m/z = 667.5 [M + H]+. Separately, DIEA (65 mg, 0.50 mmol) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 17 (50 mg, 0.10 mmol) and HATU (42 mg, 0.11 mmol) in DMF (8 mL). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min; then, crude deprotected amine obtained from compound 51 (90 mg, 0.10 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. Purification of the residue by prep-TLC (10% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.5) gave compound 13 (80 mg, 70%) as a yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.82 min, m/z = 1150.2 [M + H]+.

    4-((S)-2-(1-((5-(2,5-Dioxo-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrrol-1-yl)pentyl)carbamoyl)cyclobutane-1-carboxamido)-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl (3-(2-(4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)ethoxy)-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenyl)carbamate (13a)

    To a solution of compound 13 (50 mg, 0.04 mmol) and compound 44(45) (96 mg, 0.13 mmol) in DMF (10 mL) at 23 °C were added HOBt (12 mg, 0.09 mmol) and pyridine (34 mg, 0.44 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 38 °C for 1 h. The mixture was then concentrated, and the residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 32–62%/0.225% FA in H2O) to give compound 13a (15 mg, 19%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.75 min, m/z = 873.8 [M/2 + H]+. HRMS (ESI, 0–95_1_4min): m/z = 1745.66 [M + H]+.

    Benzyl (2-(3-Amino-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4S)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenoxy)ethyl)carbamate (53)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 50 (185 mg, 0.37 mmol) and compound 52(17) (360 mg, 0.77 mmol) in DMF (5.0 mL) were added DIEA (237 mg, 1.84 mmol) and HATU (154 mg, 0.40 mmol). The formed mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 0.5 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (8% MeOH in DCM) to afford compound 53 (220 mg, 69%) as a pale-yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.72 min, m/z = 801.3 [M + H]+.

    N-(2-(3-Amino-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4S)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenoxy)ethyl)-4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (14)

    TMSI (275 mg, 1.37 mmol) was added to a solution of compound 53 (220 mg, 0.27 mmol) in DCM (4 mL) at 23 °C. The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h; then, the volatiles were removed in vacuo. The residue was triturated with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL) to afford the crude deprotected amine (not shown, 253 mg, 100%) as a yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.74 min, m/z = 667.3 [M + H]+. Separately, DIEA (177 mg, 1.37 mmol) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 17 (137 mg, 0.27 mmol) and HATU (115 mg, 0.30 mmol) in DMF (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min; then, the crude deprotected amine obtained from compound 53 (253 mg, 0.27 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. Purification of the residue by prep-TLC (12% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.5) gave compound 14 (110 mg, 32%) as a pale-yellow solid. LCMS (10–80, AB, 2.0 min): RT = 0.98 min, m/z = 575.3 [M/2 + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.84 (s, 1H), 7.94 (s, 1H), 7.86 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (s, 1H), 7.41–7.39 (m, 5H), 7.31 (s, 1H), 7.23–7.21 (m, 3H), 4.64–4.55 (m, 8H), 4.53–4.46 (m, 3H), 4.40–4.34 (m, 3H), 4.11–4.07 (m, 2H), 3.98–3.94 (m, 2H), 3.73–3.69 (m, 5H), 3.68–3.63 (m, 3H), 2.89 (s, 3H), 2.79–2.73 (m, 3H), 2.44 (s, 4H), 2.41–2.38 (m, 1H), 2.00–1.92 (m, 2H), 0.97 (s, 9H).

    4-((S)-2-(1-((5-(2,5-Dioxo-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrrol-1-yl)pentyl)carbamoyl)cyclobutane-1-carboxamido)-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl (3-(2-(4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)ethoxy)-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4S)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenyl)carbamate (14a)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 14 (100 mg, 0.09 mmol) and compound 44(45) (192 mg, 0.26 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) were added HOBt (24 mg, 0.17 mmol) and pyridine (69 mg, 0.87 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 38 °C for 24 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 40–50%/0.225% FA in H2O) to give compound 14a (24 mg, 15%) as a pale-yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.77 min, m/z = 874.1 [M/2 + H]+. HRMS (ESI, 5–95 AB, 4 min): m/z = 1746.68 [M + H]+.

    4-((S)-2-(1-((5-(2,5-Dioxo-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrrol-1-yl)pentyl)carbamoyl)cyclobutane-1-carboxamido)-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl (3-(2-(((benzyloxy)carbonyl)amino)ethoxy)-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenyl)carbamate (16)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 51 (100 mg, 0.12 mmol) and compound 44(45) (138 mg, 0.19 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) were added HOBt (17 mg, 0.12 mmol) and pyridine (99 mg, 1.25 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 38 °C for 24 h and then concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by prep-HPLC (MeCN 43–63%/0.225% FA in H2O) provided compound 16 (21 mg, 12%) as a pale-yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.91 min, m/z = 699.8 [M/2 + H]+.

    tert-Butyl 2-(3-(2-Aminoethoxy)-5-hydroxyphenethoxy)acetate (55)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 54(16) (270 mg, 0.61 mmol) in THF (5 mL) was added 10% palladium on carbon (194 mg). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C under H2 (15 psi) for 1 h whereupon TLC analysis (30% EtOAc in petroleum ether) showed that most of the starting material was consumed. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated to give the crude compound 55 (188 mg, 100%) as a colorless oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.71 min, m/z = 311.9 [M + H]+.

    tert-Butyl 2-(3-(2-(4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)ethoxy)-5-hydroxyphenethoxy)acetate (56)

    Compound 17 (121 mg, 0.24 mmol), HATU (92 mg, 0.24 mmol), and DIEA (104 mg, 0.80 mmol) were added sequentially to a solution of crude compound 55 (50 mg, 0.16 mmol) in DMF (4 mL) at 23 °C. The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel eluting with 0–10% MeOH in DCM to give compound 56 (85 mg, 60%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.73 min, m/z = 794.2 [M + H]+.

    4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-N-(2-(3-hydroxy-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenoxy)ethyl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (15)

    TFA (2.0 mL) was added to a 23 °C solution of compound 56 (85 mg, 0.11 mmol) in DCM (2 mL). The mixture was stirred at that temperature for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo to give the crude deprotected carboxylic acid (not shown, 78 mg, 99%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.76 min, m/z = 738.2 [M + H]+. This material was dissolved in DMF (4 mL) at 23 °C, and compound 32(42) (59 mg, 0.14 mmol), HATU (60 mg, 0.16 mmol), and DIEA (41 mg, 0.32 mmol) were added sequentially. The formed mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by sequential prep-TLC (10% MeOH in DCM Rf = 0.4) and prep-HPLC (MeCN 27–58%/ 0.225% FA in H2O) methods to give compound 15 (26 mg, 21%) as a white solid. LCMS (10–80, AB, 7.0 min): RT = 3.37 min, m/z = 1151.4 [M + H]+. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.82 (s, 2H), 7.93 (s, 1H), 7.84 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.67 (s, 1H), 7.43 (d, J = 10.8 Hz, 1H), 7.40–7.38 (m, 3H), 7.37–7.35 (m, 2H), 7.29 (s, 1H), 7.18 (s, 2H), 6.36–6.34 (m, 2H), 6.22–6.20 (m, 1H), 4.65–4.59 (m, 8H), 4.48 (brs, 2H), 4.36–4.32 (m, 1H), 4.09–4.06 (m, 2H), 3.96 (d, J = 2.8 Hz, 2H), 3.88–3.85 (m, 1H), 3.80–3.76 (m, 1H), 3.72–3.64 (m, 6H), 2.90 (s, 3H), 2.78 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 2.42 (s, 3H), 2.24–2.19 (m, 2H), 2.09–2.03 (m, 2H), 0.98 (s, 9H).

    (9H-Fluoren-9-yl)methyl(S)-(1-((4-(bromomethyl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxo-5-ureidopentan-2-yl)carbamate (58)

    Compound 57(46) (1.00 g, 1.99 mmol) was dissolved in 35% HBr in HOAc (15 mL) at 23 °C. The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then poured into 0 °C H2O (20 mL). The resulting precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with MTBE (2 × 20 mL) to give the crude compound 58 (1.00 g, 89%) as a gray solid. This material was used in the next step without additional purification. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.783 min, m/z = 566.8 [M + 2 + H]+.

    tert-Butyl 2-(3-(2-((tert-Butoxycarbonyl)amino)ethoxy)-5-hydroxyphenethoxy)acetate (59)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 55 (200 mg, 0.64 mmol) and Et3N (98 mg, 0.96 mmol) in DCM (10 mL) was added Boc2O (140 mg, 0.64 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (5% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.5) to give compound 59 (260 mg, 87%) as a yellow oil. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.93 min, m/z = 434.2 [M + Na – 100]+.

    tert-Butyl (S)-2-(3-((4-(2-((((9H-Fluoren-9-yl)methoxy)carbonyl)amino)-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl)oxy)-5-(2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)ethoxy)phenethoxy)acetate (60)

    A mixture of Cs2CO3 (285 mg, 0.87 mmol) and compound 59 (120 mg, 0.29 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min. Crude compound 58 (495 mg, 0.87 mmol) was then added, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h. The mixture was diluted with H2O (15 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 ×10 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (2 × 10 mL), dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (10% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.4) to afford compound 60 (50 mg, 19%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT =1.02 min, m/z = 897.4 [M + H]+.

    (S)-2-(3-((4-(2-((((9H-Fluoren-9-yl)methoxy)carbonyl)amino)-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl)oxy)-5-(2-aminoethoxy)phenethoxy)acetic Acid (61)

    To a 23 °C solution of compound 60 (50 mg, 0.055 mmol) in HFIP (4.0 mL) was added TFA (0.2 mL). The reaction solution was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude compound 61 (TFA salt, 72 mg, 99%) as a yellow oil. This material was used in the next step without additional purification. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.66 min, m/z = 740.3 [M + H]+.

    (S)-2-(3-((4-(2-((((9H-Fluoren-9-yl)methoxy)carbonyl)amino)-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl)oxy)-5-(2-(4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)ethoxy)phenethoxy)acetic Acid (62)

    A solution of compound 17 (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), DIEA (39 mg, 0.30 mmol), and HATU (42 mg, 0.11 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) was stirred at 23 °C for 10 min. The crude compound 61 (68 mg, 0.08 mmol) was then added, and the resulting mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was subsequently concentrated, and the residue was triturated with DCM (10 mL). The precipitate that formed was collected by filtration and was washed with DCM (5 mL) to afford compound 62 (50 mg, 41%) as a yellow solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.87 min, m/z = 1222.3 [M + H]+.

    (9H-Fluoren-9-yl)methyl ((S)-1-((4-((3-(2-(4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)ethoxy)-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenoxy)methyl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxo-5-ureidopentan-2-yl)carbamate (63)

    To a solution of compound 62 (50 mg, 0.04 mmol) in DMF (4 mL) were sequentially added 32(42) (21 mg, 0.05 mmol), HATU (17 mg, 0.04 mmol), and DIEA (16 mg, 0.12 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h and then concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by prep-TLC (10% MeOH in DCM, Rf = 0.3) to give compound 64 (15 mg, 22%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.75 min, m/z = 817.8 [M/2 + H]+.

    N-(2-(3-((4-((S)-2-Qmino-5-ureidopentanamido)benzyl)oxy)-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenoxy)ethyl)-4-(3,5-difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamide (64)

    A mixture of compound 63 (15 mg, 0.01 mmol) and piperidine (0.01 mL, 0.02 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) was stirred at 23 °C for 2 h. The mixture was then concentrated to give the crude compound 64 (12 mg, 93%) as a white solid. This material was used in the next step without additional purification. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.77 min, m/z = 1412.9 [M + H]+.

    N-((S)-1-((4-((3-(2-(4-(3,5-Difluoropyridin-2-yl)-10-methyl-7-((methylsulfonyl)methyl)-11-oxo-3,4,10,11-tetrahydro-1H-1,4,10-triazadibenzo[cd,f]azulene-6-carboxamido)ethoxy)-5-(2-(2-(((S)-1-((2S,4R)-4-hydroxy-2-((4-(4-methylthiazol-5-yl)benzyl)carbamoyl)pyrrolidin-1-yl)-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)amino)-2-oxoethoxy)ethyl)phenoxy)methyl)phenyl)amino)-1-oxo-5-ureidopentan-2-yl)-N-(5-(2,5-dioxo-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrrol-1-yl)pentyl)cyclobutane-1,1-dicarboxamide (15a)

    To a solution of compound 64 (12 mg, 0.01 mmol) in DMF (4 mL) were sequentially added compound 65(47) (3.2 mg, 0.01 mmol), HATU (4.9 mg, 0.01 mmol), and DIEA (3.5 mg, 0.03 mmol). The mixture was stirred at 23 °C for 1 h and then concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by prep-HPLC (MeCN 37–67%/0.225% FA in H2O) to afford compound 15a (4.9 mg, 33%) as a white solid. LCMS (5–95, AB, 1.5 min): RT = 0.84 min, m/z = 852.3 [M/2 + H]+. HRMS (ESI, 0–95_1_4 min): m/z = 1702.68 [M + H]+.
